Data.Desc: Multiple-reel films had appeared in the United States as early as 1907, when Adolph Zukor distributed Pathé’s three-reel Passion Play.
By 1914, however, several national feature-distribution alliances that correlated pricing with a film’s negative cost and box-office receipts were organized.
Delayed by countersuits and by World War I, the government’s case was eventually won, and the MPPC formally dissolved in 1918, although it had been functionally inoperative since 1914.
Hollywood studio system, which dominated urban exhibition from the 1920s to the ’50s.
First National Pictures, Inc., a circuit of independent exhibitors who established their own production facilities in Burbank, California, in 1922.
